summary: On December 11, 2018, the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia entered a final judgment against the Democratic National Committee and its former chairwoman, Debbie Wasserman Schultz, for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Orlando, Florida, alleges that the Democratic Party and Wasserman Schultz violated Section 10 of the Exchange Act by improperly tipping the scales in favor of one candidate over all of the other Democratic candidates.  According to the complaint, Wasserman Schultz and her husband, Mark W. Bochese, falsely claimed that the DNC and Ms. Wasserman Schultz had a fiduciary duty to the DNC to support Secretary Clinton in the Democratic primary process.  In reality, the complaint alleges, the defendants did not, and did not allege, that they had a duty to do so.  Instead, they allegedly relied on the defendants’ false statements and omissions to the detriment of the Democratic donor class.  As alleged in the SEC’s complaint, the Defendants violated Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a) ofÂ the Securities Act of 1933.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the Complaint, Defendants have consented to the entry of judgments that permanently enjoin them from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, order them to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and impose civil penalties of up to $100,000.  Wasserman Schultz has also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $75,000, which is equal to the amount of her disgorgment.  On December 13, 2020, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action against the Defendants, charging them with violations of Section 15(a)(2) of Exchange Act Rule 15a-3 thereunder, and with aiding and abetting the Defendants’ violations of Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4)-8 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940. The SEC is seeking a permanent injunction against future violations of Rule 15b2-1, and a judgment ordering the Defendants to pay civil penalties in amounts to be determined by the court upon motion of the SEC.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-01-2019.   The Complaint also charges the Defendants with violating Sections 206 (1) and 206 (2) and 207 (4) of Securities Act Rule 206 (4).
